I was a UPS driver in Central Florida and picked up some of this product occasionally in 5 gallon paint buckets from a large citrus packer in the city of Frostproof being shipped overnight to Japan. The man on the shipping dock said  it was being used for Perfume. It was insured for $32,000 and was just the packed in a hard plastic paint bucket with a metal semi-circle handle,  in a plastic bag. In the 1980's, the was a crapload of money. Back then, with the college kids we had working in the Orlando hub,  that I have personally seen stack 17" inch computer monitors 10 high just to watch them get knocked over,  the chances of it making it all the way were slim. I can't imagine a bucket of this stuff leaking out. The place would smell like citrus for decades. At least with Next Day Air service UPS will only have it 24 hours and wouldn't be handling it long. Once it got to Japan it would be handled by mature adults.

Every single person now thinks that liquid smells wonderful strong of oranges, but you are so very wrong and every dam video show exactly the same and never tell that it doesn't smell good and how to get the orange smell out form it. The liquid in the video and every other contain around 97% L-limonene and around 3% D-limonene, L-limonene smells really bad like turpentine and D-limonene smells very strong of oranges and is the stuff you want but can't smell it due to the high concentration of L-limonene. I've watched the one on making soaps and thought it would be cool to add some essential oils. After seeing this video I figured that one could probably distill those oneself.
